channel.title: Projects on Aditi Ashutosh Mavalankar
channel.description: Recent content in Projects on Aditi Ashutosh Mavalankar

item.title: Advanced Bayesian Methods for Graph-based Recommendations
item.description:
This project (done by a team of 3 members) extends the work done by Lopes et al. in their paper ‘Efficient Bayesian Methods for Graph-based Recommendation’. The authors suggest 3-step paths from the target user to each candidate item, and then use probabilistic methods to rank all these candidate items for recommendation.

We incorporate the basic idea of quantifying similarity between users and items into the existing ranking methods that the original paper uses. Our results show an improvement over the performance of the original paper in all 4 metrics that the authors have used. We perform ablation experiments to see which similarity/similarities will result in the highest improvement over the baseline performance. We also use a user reliability score, which is a global measure for every user, but that leads to a decrease in performance as it is highly generalized.

We repeat the same set of experiments for 2 datasets, in order to establish the generic nature of our extensions. Our baseline performance matches that of the original paper, which validates our implementation. The results obtained for both these datasets are comparable, and this shows the robustness of our added measures of user-user similarity and item-item similarity.

For the code, please visit this Github page. The report can be found here.

item.title: Learning with Deep Neural Networks using Automated Reasoning
item.description: I recently started working with Prof. Sicun Gao on a project involving incorporating existing rules into a neural network for computer vision related tasks like object detection and tracking. Keep checking this page for further updates on code and results!

item.title: Political Social Networks
item.description:
I have always been extremely interested in studying politics and social networks. I am extremely fortunate to be working on a project with Prof. Julian McAuley in this area.

I am concentrating on the Indian political system in this project. To this, I first performed an exploratory analysis of the data I collected from the website of the Indian Government. This data contains the following details:

  • Member details
    • Name of member
    • Political Party
    • Constituency
    • State
    • Margin he/she won by
  • Debate details
    • Date debate was held
    • Members who took part
    • Topics the debate involved

I have put together a dataset combining all these details. Furthermore, I performed a thorough analysis of the data, results and code for which can be found in this Github repository.

The next step in this project, which I am working on, involves converting the data into a signed social network, and predicting interactions between members based on the graph structure and nature of the links in this graph. Local and global relevance of members, based on the number of times they interacted in the Parliament, the margin they won by in the elections, and the topics they talked about, will be used to predict interactions between members by employing principles of recommender systems.

item.title: Early Research Scholars Program, UC San Diego
item.description:
Early Research Scholars Program is an initiative funded by the National Science Foundation and conducted by Prof. Christine Alvarado at UC San Diego to encourage CS undergraduate students in their sophomore and junior years to pursue research in the field. Students work in groups of 4 for three academic quarters under the guidance of a faculty member in the CS department on their own research project. This involves submitting a research proposal at the end of the first quarter, implementing and evaluating it in the next two quarters, and presenting a poster at the end of the academic year.

It has been my honour to work with Prof. Alvarado on this project, and a great joy to have worked with some of the brightest undergraduates here at UC San Diego. Check out the projects and more program details here.

item.title: Medical Named Entity Recognition in Twitter data
Music Lab - IIIT-H Virtual Labs
item.description:
I worked as a Research Assistant in VLEAD at IIIT-Hyderabad under the guidance of Prof. Venkatesh Choppella. My project involved building a virtual lab for Indian classical music.

One set of experiments involved generating questions and answers automatically from a music ontology. This work was published in the 7th IEEE International Conference on Technology for Education (T4E), 2015.

item.title: Strategezing the next move in Backgammon
